componenttextpreview: Sure. This is Paul. Just for the benefit of the entire listening group, as we talked about in the third quarter, we are adding a total of 6 properties to our same-store pool for 2016. And those are Pacific Bay Vistas, 2900 on First, 21 Fitzsimons, Trimont
componenttext: Sure. This is Paul. Just for the benefit of the entire listening group, as we talked about in the third quarter, we are adding a total of 6 properties to our same-store pool for 2016. And those are Pacific Bay Vistas, 2900 on First, 21 Fitzsimons, Trimont, Saberpoint and Eastpointe. And so the impact of those 3 -- of those 6 properties in total is roughly a 20 basis point impact to revenues for 2016.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you'd be pretty close with the 2015 results exclusive of those redevelopment properties?
componenttext: Okay. So you'd be pretty close with the 2015 results exclusive of those redevelopment properties?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay. And then in terms of the rolling off of the tax credits over the next couple of years, does that give you guys the ability to accelerate dispositions on Affordable product? And how should we kind of think about that?
componenttext: Yes. Okay. And then in terms of the rolling off of the tax credits over the next couple of years, does that give you guys the ability to accelerate dispositions on Affordable product? And how should we kind of think about that?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Aaron, this is Terry. You're exactly right. Once tax credits are delivered and compliance periods are in, then the properties are more marketable. We've long said that we expect to liquidate those properties as those conditions are met. And so we would ex
componenttext: Aaron, this is Terry. You're exactly right. Once tax credits are delivered and compliance periods are in, then the properties are more marketable. We've long said that we expect to liquidate those properties as those conditions are met. And so we would expect to see that roll off.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And is that disposition activity timed with the rolling off of the tax credits embedded in the forward 2-year guidance?
componenttext: And is that disposition activity timed with the rolling off of the tax credits embedded in the forward 2-year guidance?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Within the forward 2-year guidance, there is not the expectation or ability in that 2-year window to sell a meaningful portion of the tax credit properties, although we will continue to work with our investors to see if we can't strike a deal that would b
componenttext: Within the forward 2-year guidance, there is not the expectation or ability in that 2-year window to sell a meaningful portion of the tax credit properties, although we will continue to work with our investors to see if we can't strike a deal that would be beneficial to both us and them. John, would you like to add anything?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I agree.
componenttext: No, I agree.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a time lag between the delivery of the credits and the 5-year compliance period. And so it's after the delivery of the credits but during the compliance period when these properties will be sold. And some of them will be sold in that first year an
componenttext: There's a time lag between the delivery of the credits and the 5-year compliance period. And so it's after the delivery of the credits but during the compliance period when these properties will be sold. And some of them will be sold in that first year and some will be sold until the end of the fifth.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Drew Babin of Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Drew Babin of Robert W. Baird.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the spirit of short-term pain for long-term gain, are asset sales to deleverage something that you thought about? I just know in the guidance that it -- has leverage kind of gone down at a slower rate than it has over the last year or 2? I'm just curio
componenttext: In the spirit of short-term pain for long-term gain, are asset sales to deleverage something that you thought about? I just know in the guidance that it -- has leverage kind of gone down at a slower rate than it has over the last year or 2? I'm just curious whether there may be any kind of larger moves potentially in there.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Paul. I'll start with that [indiscernible] and then hand it over to Terry for his thoughts. If you look at our deleveraging that has been accomplished over the past few years, certainly a portion of that was accomplished through property sal
componenttext: Drew, this is Paul. I'll start with that [indiscernible] and then hand it over to Terry for his thoughts. If you look at our deleveraging that has been accomplished over the past few years, certainly a portion of that was accomplished through property sales, but really what moved the dial significantly was the equity offering that we completed last January. And so as we put together our thoughts for the next few years, our focus was on keeping the total quantum of leverage about constant, and that when you combine it with expected EBITDA growth provides opportunity for a meaningful reduction in leverage ratios, approaching the low 6s. And so at that point, as I think about it and as we have discussed as the management team here, that feels right for Aimco and the company, but we will of course continue to monitor what is appropriate given the economic environment. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Paul, I think you said it exactly right. For the moment, we've said our target to be between 6x and 7x leverage or x EBITDA leverage x EBITDA. And at this time in the cycle we'd like to be closer to 6x. We get there in these next couple of years. An
componenttext: Well, Paul, I think you said it exactly right. For the moment, we've said our target to be between 6x and 7x leverage or x EBITDA leverage x EBITDA. And at this time in the cycle we'd like to be closer to 6x. We get there in these next couple of years. And as always, with Aimco, you have to adjust that we have the safest balance sheet because we have the longest duration, we have the least exposure to refunding risk, the least exposure to repricing risk, the lease exposure to entity risk, and we don't have a business model that's exposed to construction completion. So the balance sheet, we think, is in good shape today and gets -- continues to get better over the next couple of years.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just a second question on your outlook for '16 and -- your guidance for '16 and your confidence in putting out a '17 outlook. Can you point to specific factors that give you kind of the confidence necessary to go out 2 years with your assumptions? And
componenttext: And just a second question on your outlook for '16 and -- your guidance for '16 and your confidence in putting out a '17 outlook. Can you point to specific factors that give you kind of the confidence necessary to go out 2 years with your assumptions? And I guess more specifically, in the Boston market, do you expect any pickup from GE moving their headquarters there? Is that something material that could kind of benefit that market?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll speak to how we put together the model and then look to Keith or Terry to discuss the impact on the moving of the GE's headquarters to Boston. As we look to the model, the 2016 guidance was based upon the process that we have followed for a num
componenttext: Maybe I'll speak to how we put together the model and then look to Keith or Terry to discuss the impact on the moving of the GE's headquarters to Boston. As we look to the model, the 2016 guidance was based upon the process that we have followed for a number of years, and that is a bottoms-up property-by-property examination of those prospects all up, and that's how we set our guidance. For 2017, because that is a period that is beyond the time horizon, which we have great visibility, we wanted to provide a model. And so in that model, we are using third party's expectations for what will happen in our particular submarkets for new lease rents. We also have assumed what we feel is a conservative assumption regarding renewal rates where we are assuming in the '17 model a 4.5% renewal rate, which is 90 basis points below what we have experienced recently. And so we think the combination of those 2 factors allow us to provide a broad range of potential outcomes for the investors to see what might happen under that set of particular set of facts. And of course, we will continue to operate the properties to the best of our performance. And we'll see what we can do to beat that. And then I guess as far as our thoughts on Boston, Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John?
componenttext: John?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just in terms of Boston, we kind of tune into it because of the recent activity we had there and the coming delivery of One Canal. My understanding is that GE, their corporate headquarters move involves really only about 600 employees, so it's not go
componenttext: Yes. Just in terms of Boston, we kind of tune into it because of the recent activity we had there and the coming delivery of One Canal. My understanding is that GE, their corporate headquarters move involves really only about 600 employees, so it's not going to be a dial mover for demand in Downtown Boston. It certainly is a big charge for the locals in terms of landing a major corporate headquarters and a continued trend to definition of Boston as a major financial center. And so we think that's certainly good news, but we don't think it's going to move the dial on demand in Boston.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question will come from John Pawlowski of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: And our next question will come from John Pawlowski of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: One follow up to Drew's question there. I guess, what specifically would you need to see in the macro environment to change that 2-year plan of gradual deleveraging versus ramping dispositions to delever more meaningfully?
componenttext: One follow up to Drew's question there. I guess, what specifically would you need to see in the macro environment to change that 2-year plan of gradual deleveraging versus ramping dispositions to delever more meaningfully?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'd have to see some consequential change, better or worse, to change our plans. Based on what we know today, we think that bringing our balance sheet leverage down further and faster is an indicator. We appreciate your compass and score of our leverage,
componenttext: We'd have to see some consequential change, better or worse, to change our plans. Based on what we know today, we think that bringing our balance sheet leverage down further and faster is an indicator. We appreciate your compass and score of our leverage, and we think that we're in the right place right now. If the world was a little different, we'll react.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last question. Should we interpret guidance for no new acquisitions in '16 and '17 as a hard commitment, or a soft commitment based on just the opportunities that you see today?
componenttext: Okay. Last question. Should we interpret guidance for no new acquisitions in '16 and '17 as a hard commitment, or a soft commitment based on just the opportunities that you see today?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I'm really glad you asked that question, because I think it's important to clarify that. In the last 5 years, we have sold more than 200 properties for more than $2.5 billion, about 1/4 of our enterprise value and more than all or almost all of our
componenttext: John, I'm really glad you asked that question, because I think it's important to clarify that. In the last 5 years, we have sold more than 200 properties for more than $2.5 billion, about 1/4 of our enterprise value and more than all or almost all of our peers proportionately. During that same time, we've acquired only 15 properties for about $600 million over 5 years. Our appetite for acquisitions is under control, and its disciplined application is clear in the portfolio transformation, where rents have more than doubled over the past 7 or 8 years. When we look forward, we will continue to apply that same paired trade discipline and only make an acquisition where it's clearly accretive and to the advantage of our shareholders.

componenttext: And the next question comes from John Kim of BMO.

componenttext: What I would add to that is, as John told you in the last call, our rent growth assumption after lease-up or during lease-up is 3.6%. In our guidance and forecast, we've assumed 0 rent increase. And as we pointed out what we're experiencing nearby has remained strong.

componenttext: I think you flagged the time it's taken to stabilize, but is there something you could have done differently to neutralize the earnings dilution as far as structuring the deal or maybe delaying the timing of disposition?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not especially. And this really goes back to a question we had, I think, from Nick early on, which is how do you balance your thinking about accounting and reported earnings versus net asset value creation and so forth. And we're highly focused on net ass
componenttext: Not especially. And this really goes back to a question we had, I think, from Nick early on, which is how do you balance your thinking about accounting and reported earnings versus net asset value creation and so forth. And we're highly focused on net asset value creation. We are mindful of current period earnings. We know we're going to have to explain short-term dilution, but we're not attracted to financial structures or accounting gimmicks that mask or confuse the basic business we're in.

componenttext: Okay. And then on your same-store growth in '17, it's noticeably lower than UDR, which is the only other company that's provided it. I realize I think you're using market estimates, but you know your assets better than they do. So are you -- do you think your projections actually are reflective of what you're going to achieve?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would say, John, is first of all, I want to talk about UDR, because they are a terrific company, and out here in the world of Broncos fans, we all stick together. So I don't want to, in any way, have a different view than what Tom and his very able
componenttext: What I would say, John, is first of all, I want to talk about UDR, because they are a terrific company, and out here in the world of Broncos fans, we all stick together. So I don't want to, in any way, have a different view than what Tom and his very able team are doing. For Aimco, we expressly did not make a forecast of what we think our results are going to be in 2017. And it's because, as I said earlier, we're getting conflicting data. When we look inside our own portfolio, we see acceleration, not deceleration. When we read thoughtful analysts, like Dan, and we read our opinions of the reports of world markets and financial markets, we see noise and concern. And so what we did in 2017 forecast, as Paul said, and I just want everyone to get it clearly, we created a financial model. It is not our forecast, it is not our making a call on rents. It's just as, if these things were to happen, which is to say if the third-party data providers were correct that new lease rents were to drop by 60 bps, and if our renewal rents were to drop by as much as 90 bps. As Keith mentioned earlier, right now that's going the other way, but if those things were to happen, then this would be the impact in 2017.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: But isn't that like the tail wagging the dog? I mean, you know your assets from the ground up better. There are certain assets stabilizing in '17 or before and then the reason Axiom, they're taking probably a ground up but also macro approach. I would thi
componenttext: But isn't that like the tail wagging the dog? I mean, you know your assets from the ground up better. There are certain assets stabilizing in '17 or before and then the reason Axiom, they're taking probably a ground up but also macro approach. I would think that we would want to use your estimates or, at least, get your insight of where you think growth is actually going to be.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our insight is -- let me be clear. Our insight is that right now everything we see is getting better and is accelerating. And so that -- we also know that can't go on forever, and we also know it's very hard to predict the future. And so when we loo
componenttext: Well, our insight is -- let me be clear. Our insight is that right now everything we see is getting better and is accelerating. And so that -- we also know that can't go on forever, and we also know it's very hard to predict the future. And so when we look at 2017, what we want to do is give a model rather than a detailed opinion from the company.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Nick Yulico of UBS.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on your redevelopment development forecast. You're talking about $200 million to $300 million a year spending basis, I think, you said going all the way out to 2018 in your 2-year plan what with new starts. And I'm wondering how comm
componenttext: I just had a question on your redevelopment development forecast. You're talking about $200 million to $300 million a year spending basis, I think, you said going all the way out to 2018 in your 2-year plan what with new starts. And I'm wondering how committed you are to that? Because each time you start these redevelopments they're multi-years out, and you're selling assets at essentially the same cap rate where you're saying to get your redevelopment yield and yet you're getting the NOI from the redevelopment 2 years later. It just feels like a very dilutive process. I'm wondering how committed you are? And how we should think about modeling this over the next 3, 4 years? Because I think it's one of the reasons why your 2017 forecast for FFO missed the Street.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, again, this goes back to a very thoughtful question, which was asked the very first question by a thoughtful analyst, which is you, which is what is the balance between current period profitability and net asset value creation. We do try and strike
componenttext: Nick, again, this goes back to a very thoughtful question, which was asked the very first question by a thoughtful analyst, which is you, which is what is the balance between current period profitability and net asset value creation. We do try and strike a balance. What we see in the redevelopment activities is, there's typically a year or 2 before the current period profitability of the redeveloped asset catches up to that of the property being sold. I've kind of forgotten right here, but I believe that in the 2015 property sales the free cash flow yield was just under 5%, something like that, 4% and change, 4% high. And that when we look forward, that might take -- and it depends on the redevelopment what the cycle time is. So at Park Towne, you can see the cycle time is probably 6 to 9 months. At another one -- Ocean House, it was over a year. And so we try to do them in smaller bites where the cycle time is faster, trying to stay focused on long-term value creation and accept the turbulence[ph].

componenttext: Anthony, John Bezzant here. I would say the execution of getting them sold, and the pricing is really not a whole lot different than it was a year ago. Whether that was that people had filled their orders for the year, whether the -- just seasonal flow, whatever it was, but -- so maybe the bid lists weren't quite as thick as they were in June. componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Aimco First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn. Please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of w
componenttext:
Thank you. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measure such as adjusted funds from operations and funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website. Prepared remarks today come from Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO; Keith Kimmel, our Executive Vice President in charge of property operations; John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer; and Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. A question-and-answer session will follow our prepared remarks. 
I will now turn the call over to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you and thank you for your interest in Aimco. Business is good. In property operations, same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.1%. The rate of increase 70 basis point better than the 4.4% growth rate of t
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you and thank you for your interest in Aimco. 
Business is good. In property operations, same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.1%. The rate of increase 70 basis point better than the 4.4% growth rate of the first quarter last year. Operating expenses were essentially flat with higher rents and flat expenses, same-store net operating income was up by more than 7%, beating the high end of our guidance by 160 basis points making for a good quarter and a solid start to the year. 
In redevelopment, ongoing projects are on-time, on budget and are creating value equal to $0.25 to $0.35 for each dollar invested. Patty and her team are doing a great job, including construction on -- completing construction on the south tower and starting construction on the east tower at Park Towne Place in Center City, Philadelphia as well as adding to our active redevelopments by starting the final space that completes the redevelopment of The Sterling in Center City, Philadelphia and starting a second phase at Palazzo at Park La Brea in Los Angeles. 
In portfolio management, first quarter revenue per apartment home was up across the entire Aimco portfolio to more than $1,860, an Aimco record and up 9% year-over-year. 
For these good results, I offer sincere graduations and thanks to my Aimco teammates, both here in Denver and across the country. It's a privilege and a pleasure to work with you. I'm especially proud of your great Aimco a top workplace in Colorado for a fourth consecutive year. 
Now for a more detailed report in first quarter operations, I'd like to  turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of property operations. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. We're pleased to report that we had solid quarter and operations with revenues up 4.8% year-over-year, expenses were up 10 basis points year-over-year with net operating income up 7.1% for the quarter. Each of this quarter metrics are bette
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. We're pleased to report that we had solid quarter and operations with revenues up 4.8% year-over-year, expenses were up 10 basis points year-over-year with net operating income up 7.1% for the quarter. Each of this quarter metrics are better than the first quarter of last year. 
In Q1 of 2016, our residents gave us our 10th consecutive quarter better than a 4-star rating in customer satisfaction. This contributed to renewal rent increases of 6% for the quarter, some 120 basis points higher than the first quarter of 2015. 
Of note, renewal premiums increased in each successive month of the quarter. We saw particularly strength in the Bay Area, Denver and Atlanta. Renewal rents in these markets increased 8% to 9% compared to the expiring leases. 
Where those leases expired and were not renewed, our new lease pricing outperformed the results from the first quarter of 2015 and for each month of the quarter, individually. This resulted in a quarterly increase in new lease rates of 3.5%, 230 basis points better than last year. The year-over-year rate of growth for new leases was strongest in Boston and Los Angeles.
As a result of our team's hard work, our blended lease rate increases of 4.6% were 180 basis points higher than the first quarter of last year and by 100 basis points sequentially, all while increasing average daily occupancy for the quarter by 10 basis points year-over-year and 50 basis points from fourth quarter. 
We had another solid quarter on the expense front, growing by 10 basis points overall and 2% when excluding the year-over-year decline in utility expenses due to a milder winter.
Turnover for the quarter was 50.9%. Of the customers who decided to move-out, 23% were for career moves, 17% did not renew do price and 14% moved out to purchase homes. There are no significant changes in these move-out reasons versus recent quarters or on our long-term averages.
Our resident quality continues to improve. The average income for those new customers who moved in during the first quarter was $136,000 with a median income of $95,000. Year-over-year, the median income of our new residents was up 19% compared to the first quarter of 2015, with half coming from a more discriminating application process and half from an improvement in our portfolio quality.
Our 12 target markets, which represents 90% of same-store net operating income had top line revenue growth up 5.2% in the quarter versus 4.8% for the entire portfolio. Our top performers all had revenue increases in double digits from more than 10% to better than 13%. This was led by the Bay Area followed by Seattle and Denver.
Our strong performers, which had revenue growth from nearly 6% to better than 7% were Boston, San Diego, Atlanta and Greater Los Angeles. Our steady target markets was about 2.5% to 3% revenue growth were Chicago, New York City and Washington D.C. And finally, with softer revenue growth of around 1%, we had Philadelphia and Miami.
As we look to our April month-to-date results, blended lease rates are up 5%, 10 basis points better than last year. New leases are up 3.6% and renewals are up 6.4%. April's average daily occupancy is at 95.9%, 30 basis points below last year by design. 
We've intentionally moved leases from our shoulder months into peak pleasing season with higher demand. This improvement in expiration management will pay dividends by repricing leases in periods of greater expected rent growth. 
And finally, May and June renewal offers went up 6% to 8% increases. And with great things to our teams in the field and here in Denver for your commitment to Aimco's success. 
I'll turn the call over to John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer. John?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith, and good day, everybody. I'd like to take a few minutes to review our recent investment and portfolio activities. During the first quarter, we invested $31 million in redevelopment, $9 million of it on our redevelopment pipeline and $22 m
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith, and good day, everybody. I'd like to take a few minutes to review our recent investment and portfolio activities. 
During the first quarter, we invested $31 million in redevelopment, $9 million of it on our redevelopment pipeline and $22 million at Park Towne Place and The Sterling both located in Center City, Philadelphia. 
At Park Towne Place, we completed redevelopment of the south tower and the town center, 91% of the 224 completed development homes in the south tower are leased and rents are ahead of underwriting. Construction is progressing as planned on the east tower with deliveries of first redeveloped apartment homes coming this summer. Early leasing results are encouraging as we continue to see strong demand. 
We also continued our phased redevelopment of The Sterling with 95% of the 283 completed apartment home leased or rented or underwriting. 
Patty and her team continue to plan her next round of development and as Terry mentions, we are continuing that redevelopment at The Sterling and Palazzo Park La Brea. 
At The Sterling, the final phase of redevelopment included 125 apartment homes on 7 floors and the build out of the retail space. The incremental cost of this work is approximately $22 million. 
We're also moving forward on the continued redevelopment of our Palazzo Park La Brea property in Los Angeles. This base will upgrade 389 apartment homes in accompanying common areas. The incremental investment there is approximately $24 million with Aimco share about $13 million.
During the first quarter, we also invested $15 million in the construction of our One Canal development project in Boston. We anticipate receiving our initial temporary certificate of occupancy for the building within the next few days and our first move-ins are scheduled for mid-May. To-tate, 12% of the 310 apartment homes have been leased and rents there also above underwriting. 
In addition to One Canal, we have 3 other properties [indiscernible] going lease-up Axiom, Vivo and Indigo and when we're on track at each. Our lease-up of Axiom and Vivo, the properties we acquired last year in Cambridge, is progressing well. Axiom, which we acquired in construction completion last April, is now 92% leased and Vivo, which we completed construction on in October is 75% leased. Rents and lease space at both properties are exceeding our underwriting. 
At Indigo, in Redwood City, California, construction continues on plan. We're under contract to purchase this property upon construction completion and anticipate closing the acquisition before our next call. We have commenced leasing in this property and at least 9% of the 463 apartment homes also at rent in excess of our underwriting. 
On the disposition side, we sold One Conventional property during the first quarter for $10 million in gross proceeds. We continue to expect to execute the bulk of our property sales in the second and fourth quarters as we match-fund our planned investment activities. 
And while we don't normally talk about our sales activities prior to closing, many of you are aware that our buyer on River side, Washington REIT, disclosed transaction details on their call yesterday. We can confirm that the details disclosed by them and anticipate closing this transaction during the second quarter. The proceeds from the sale of River die and will complete the funding of our Indigo acquisition. 
And with that, I would now like to turn the call over to our Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. Paul?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I will start today with first quarter 2016 results. At $0.51 per share, AFFO was up 11% year-over-year and $0.05 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.57 per share was up 10% fuel year-over-year $0.03 ahe
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I will start today with first quarter 2016 results. At $0.51 per share, AFFO was up 11% year-over-year and $0.05 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.57 per share was up 10% fuel year-over-year $0.03 ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. First quarter AFFO out-performance of $0.05 per share was driven by $0.02 from same-store net operating income out-performance 210 basis points, $0.01 from the timing of income tax-related items and $0.02 from the timing of capital replacement expenses. These positive first quarter results we are increasing full year AFFO and pro forma FFO guidance by $0.01 per share at their respective midpoints. This increase reflects, one, the turnaround of first quarter's $0.03 out-performance related to the timing items I just mentioned and two, the recognition of $0.01 of the first quarter's $0.02 of same-store NOI out-performance. I'd like to be clear here, we do not see slowdown in business compared to our beginning of the year expectations, however, we do prefer to take a conservative approach to raising guidance and until we have more visibility into peak leasing season.
On last night's release, we also established second quarter AFFO guidance of $0.45 to $0.49 per share and pro forma FFO guidance of $0.54 to $0.58 per share. 
Shifting gears to our operations for guidance. We're increasing our same-store NOI growth guidance to a range of 5.5% to 6.5%, an increase of 25 basis points at the midpoint. This increase reflects a 75 basis point decrease in projected operating expense growth. Our guidance for full year same-store revenue growth is unchanged at 4.75% at the midpoint.
With last night's release, we also established guidance for second quarter same-store NOI growth of 3.5% to 4.5%, which is consistent with the expectations we had for the quarter when we started the year. Now we expect to see continued solid rent growth with the year-over-year comparison for the quarter affected by 2 items. 
First, as Keith mentioned, we have undertaken to reduce the number of lease expirations occurring in off-peak months and to drive more leasing volume into peak season where we expect greater pricing power. The increased number of leased expirations will increase virtual vacancy during the second quarter, reducing average daily occupancy by 40 basis points compared to the second quarter 2015 and also increasing turnover expenses. While these costs are expected to be reversed and rewarded in other quarters, in the second quarter, they are expected to reduce year-over-year same-store NOI growth by approximately 100 basis points. 
Second, our second quarter expense growth last year was actually negative as a result of nonroutine items in 2015. So while we expect low expense growth in this year, we also expect faster expense growth in this quarter. 
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttext: It's Keith, look, let me walk with the overview of the objective and talk about what we did. When we look at the first and fourth quarter, we believe kind of having 20% of our expiring leases in each of those quarters is where we'd like to be and then putting the balance or 60% in the second and third quarters. A year ago, we moved roughly 2,000 units from the shouldering quarters and put them into the second and third quarter essentially, so we could take advantage of peak season and essentially some of this slowdowns that you can see in pricing and demand in particularly November, December things like that.

componenttextpreview: Keith Kimmel, I'll walk you through it. First, let me start with that we think using new lease pricing is the best barometer as we look across how they're performing. And if we look at our 12 target markets, what we've seen in this past quarter, is 9 out

And then the third is Chicago in which both our As and Bs are almost on top of each other. Our As is just nudge an amount probably about 10 basis points, so very, very close.

componenttext: Rob, this is Keith, I'll take it again. One of the things that we have been focused on for many years is matching our staffing levels with the demand of the business. And so we've done at this over the years. It's been an area in which we have been able to take advantage of really matching when you have those ebbs and flows. And so what I'd tell you is in January of this year and at the end of last year when I was getting the team together, we had a very focused effort on the peak season is going to come earlier, how are we going to stuff up. And it's not just our own staffing, it's vendors, it's a variety of other folks in which we get well-prepared so that we could really take advantage of it and not be in a position that it seems like you're caught off guard but in fact, it's all by plan and by design.

componenttextpreview: So you mentioned on the lease optimization process, is there any cost to that in terms of making a deal with people or whatever it to shift into the second and third quarter and is there any more of it to do?
componenttext: So you mentioned on the lease optimization process, is there any cost to that in terms of making a deal with people or whatever it to shift into the second and third quarter and is there any more of it to do?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Keith, let me help you think about it. First of all, there's no cost to it. Essentially, what happens is that we have a professional revenue management team that works in-house. And essentially when we're sending out renewal offers, what we're
componenttext: Rich, it's Keith, let me help you think about it. First of all, there's no cost to it. Essentially, what happens is that we have a professional revenue management team that works in-house. And essentially when we're sending out renewal offers, what we're able to do is we're able to stagger and offer different extensions and lengths in order to match up so that we get those leases to get renewed and/or new leases to match up into these new periods of time. So from that standpoint, there's really no difference in the way that our cost associated with that. It's more about it's just kind of walking through the process and ensuring we match it up that way.

componenttext: And then just a quick question, follow-up question unrelated. I'm curious how you feel about that? And are you -- do you have an eye towards Philly becoming -- a much better market, is that why you're developing it? Or is this kind of turning against you a little bit?

componenttext: Rich, this is Keith, I'll take the first at it and then John [indiscernible] who wants to add in. First of all, just to be on the same page, the Philadelphia market that we're seeing that's not performing at the same level as some of the others is outside of Center City. In fact, when we look at the redevelopments that we're doing at Park Towne in, Sterling, in Center City, there's not even this better located in those buildings in all of Philadelphia and in fact, those are being received and leased up above our expectations. And I would just tell you that we would not change the way we're thinking about that in any way.

componenttext: Just to double down a little bit, you recall, our conversation back in October at the Investor Day, Philadelphia, for us, long term, in the portfolio, is Center City. And our only Center City asset that in's the same-store today is River Lost, that had 4% growth, so we would not consider it to be a laggard within the portfolio at all. We have high hopes and high prospects for Center City.

Good afternoon, and welcome to the Aimco First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn. Please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of w
componenttext:
Thank you. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted funds from operations and funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website.
Prepared remarks today come from Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO; Keith Kimmel, our Executive Vice President in charge of property operations; John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer; and Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. A question-and-answer session will follow our prepared remarks.
I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you, and thank you for your interest in Aimco.Business is good. In property operations, same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.1%. The rate of increase is 70 basis points better than the 4.4% growth rate
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you, and thank you for your interest in Aimco.
Business is good. In property operations, same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.1%. The rate of increase is 70 basis points better than the 4.4% growth rate of the first quarter last year. Operating expenses were essentially flat. With higher rents and flat expenses, same-store net operating income was up by more than 7%, beating the high end of guidance by 160 basis points, making for a good quarter and a solid start to the year.
In redevelopment, ongoing projects are on time, on budget and are creating value equal to $0.25 to $0.35 for each dollar invested. Patti and her team are doing a great job, including construction on -- completing construction on the south tower and starting construction on the east tower at Park Towne Place in Center City, Philadelphia as well as adding to our active redevelopments by starting the final phase that completes redevelopment of The Sterling in Center City, Philadelphia and starting a second phase at Palazzo at Park La Brea in Los Angeles.
In portfolio management, first quarter revenue per apartment home was up across the entire Aimco portfolio to more than $1,860, an Aimco record and up 9% year-over-year.
For these good results, I offer sincere congratulations and thanks to my Aimco teammates, both here in Denver and across the country. It's a privilege and a pleasure to work with you. I'm especially proud of your grading Aimco a top workplace in Colorado for a fourth consecutive year.
Now for a more detailed report on first quarter operations, I'd like to turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of Property Operations. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. Pleased to report that we had a solid quarter and operations, with revenues up 4.8% year-over-year, expenses were up 10 basis points year-over-year with net operating income up 7.1% for the quarter. Each of this quarterly metrics are better
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. Pleased to report that we had a solid quarter and operations, with revenues up 4.8% year-over-year, expenses were up 10 basis points year-over-year with net operating income up 7.1% for the quarter. Each of this quarterly metrics are better than the first quarter of last year.
In Q1 of 2016, our residents gave us our 10th consecutive quarter better than a 4-star rating in customer satisfaction. This contributed to renewal rent increases of 6% for the quarter, some 120 basis points higher than the first quarter of 2015.
Of note, renewal premiums increased in each successive month of the quarter. We saw particular strength in the Bay Area, Denver and Atlanta. Renewal rents in these markets increased 8% to 9% compared to the expiring leases.
Whether those leases expired and were not renewed, our new lease pricing outperformed the results from the first quarter of 2015 and for each month of the quarter individually. This resulted in a quarterly increase in new lease rates of 3.5%, 230 basis points better than last year. The year-over-year rate of growth for new leases was strongest in Boston and Los Angeles.
As a result of our team's hard work, our blended lease rate increases of 4.6% were 180 basis points higher than the first quarter of last year and by 100 basis points sequentially, all while increasing average daily occupancy for the quarter by 10 basis points year-over-year and 50 basis points from fourth quarter.
We had another solid quarter on the expense front, growing by 10 basis points overall and 2% when excluding the year-over-year decline in utility expense due to a milder winter.
Turnover for the quarter was 50.9%. Of the customers who decided to move out, 23% were for career moves, 17% did not renew do to price and 14% moved out to purchase homes. There are no significant changes in these move-out reasons versus recent quarters or on long-term averages.
Our resident quality continues to improve. The average income for those new customers who moved in during the first quarter was $136,000 with a median income of $95,000. Year-over-year, the median income of our new residents was up 19% compared to the first quarter of 2015, with half coming from a more discriminating application process and half from an improvement on our portfolio quality.
Our 12 target markets, which represent 90% of same-store net operating income, had top line revenue growth up 5.2% in the quarter versus 4.8% for the entire portfolio. Our top performers all had revenue increases in double digits from more than 10% to better than 13%. This was led by the Bay Area followed by Seattle and Denver.
Our strong performers, which had revenue growth from nearly 6% to better than 7%, were Boston, San Diego, Atlanta and Greater Los Angeles. Our steady target markets with about 2.5% to 3% revenue growth were Chicago, New York City and Washington, D.C. And finally, with softer revenue growth of around 1%, we had Philadelphia and Miami.
As we look to our April month-to-date results, blended lease rates are up 5%, 10 basis points better than last year. New leases are up 3.6% and renewals are up 6.4%. April's average daily occupancy is at 95.9%, 30 basis points below last year by design.
We've intentionally moved leases from our shoulder months into peak leasing season with higher demand. This improvement in expiration management will pay dividends by repricing leases in periods of greater expected rent growth.
And finally, May and June renewal offers went up with 6% to 8% increases, and with great thanks to our teams in the field and here in Denver for your commitment to Aimco's success.
I'll turn the call over to John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer. John?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith, and good day, everybody. Today, I'd like to take a few minutes to review our recent investment and portfolio activities.During the first quarter, we invested $31 million in redevelopment, $9 million of it on our redevelopment pipeline and
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith, and good day, everybody. Today, I'd like to take a few minutes to review our recent investment and portfolio activities.
During the first quarter, we invested $31 million in redevelopment, $9 million of it on our redevelopment pipeline and $22 million at Park Towne Place and The Sterling both located in Center City, Philadelphia.
At Park Towne Place, we completed redevelopment of the south tower and the town center, 91% of the 224 completed apartment homes in the south tower are leased and rents are ahead of underwriting.
Construction is progressing as planned on the east tower with delivery of the first redeveloped apartment homes coming this summer. Early leasing results are encouraging as we continue to see strong demand.
We also continued our phased redevelopment of The Sterling with 95% of the 283 completed apartment homes leased at rents above underwriting.
Patti and her team continue to plan her next round of redevelopments. And as Terry mentioned, we are continuing that redevelopment at The Sterling and Palazzo, Park La Brea.
At The Sterling, the final phase of redevelopment includes 125 apartment homes on 7 floors and the build-out of the retail space. The incremental cost of this work is approximately $22 million.
We're also moving forward on the continued redevelopment of our Palazzo, Park La Brea property in Los Angeles. This space will upgrade 389 apartment homes and the accompanying common areas. The incremental investment there is approximately $24 million, with Aimco share about $13 million.
During the first quarter, we also invested $15 million in the construction of our One Canal development project in Boston. We anticipate receiving our initial temporary certificate of occupancy for the building within the next few days, and our first move-ins are scheduled for mid-May. To date, 12% of the 310 apartment homes have been leased and rents there are also above underwriting.
In addition to One Canal, we have 3 other properties that are going lease-up, Axiom, Vivo and Indigo, and we are on track at each. Our lease-up of Axiom and Vivo, the properties that we acquired last year in Cambridge, is progressing well. Axiom, which we acquired in construction completion last April, is now 92% leased; and Vivo, which we completed construction on in October, is 75% leased. Rents and lease space at both properties are exceeding our underwriting.
At Indigo in Redwood City, California, construction continues on plan. We're under contract to purchase this property upon construction completion and anticipate closing the acquisition before our next call. We had commenced leasing at this property and have leased 9% of the 463 apartment homes also at rents in excess of our underwriting.
On the disposition side, we sold 1 Conventional property during the first quarter for $10 million in gross proceeds. We continue to expect to execute the bulk of our property sales in the second and fourth quarters as we match-fund our planned investment activities.
And while we don't normally talk about our sales activity prior to closing, many of you are aware that our buyer on Riverside, Washington REIT, disclosed transaction details on their call yesterday. We can confirm the details disclosed by them and anticipate closing this transaction during the second quarter. The proceeds from the sale of Riverside will complete the funding of our Indigo acquisition.
And with that, I would now like to turn the call over to Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. Paul?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I will start today with first quarter 2016 results. At $0.51 per share, AFFO was up 11% year-over-year and $0.05 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.57 per share was up 10% year-over-year and $0.03 ahea
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I will start today with first quarter 2016 results. At $0.51 per share, AFFO was up 11% year-over-year and $0.05 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.57 per share was up 10% year-over-year and $0.03 ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. First quarter AFFO outperformance of $0.05 per share was driven by $0.02 from same-store net operating income outperformance, 210 basis points; $0.01 from the timing of income tax-related items; and $0.02 from the timing of capital replacements spending expenditures. With these positive first quarter results, we are increasing full year AFFO and pro forma FFO guidance by $0.01 per share at their respective midpoints. This increase reflects, one, the turnaround of first quarter's $0.03 outperformance related to the timing items I just mentioned; and two, the recognition of $0.01 of the first quarter's $0.02 of same-store NOI outperformance.
I'd like to be clear here, we do not see a slowdown in business compared to our beginning of year expectations. However, we do prefer to take a conservative approach to raising guidance and until we have more visibility into peak leasing season.
On last night's release, we also established second quarter AFFO guidance of $0.45 to $0.49 per share and pro forma FFO guidance of $0.54 to $0.58 per share.
Shifting gears to our operations-related guidance. We're increasing our same-store NOI growth guidance to a range of 5.5% to 6.5%, an increase of 25 basis points at the midpoint. This increase reflects a 75 basis point decrease in projected operating expense growth. Our guidance for full year same-store revenue growth is unchanged at 4.75% at the midpoint.
With last night's release, we also established guidance for second quarter same-store NOI growth of 3.5% to 4.5%, which is consistent with the expectations we had for the quarter when we started the year. Now as then, we expect to see continued solid rent growth with the year-over-year comparison for the quarter affected by 2 items. 
First, as Keith mentioned, we have undertaken to reduce the number of lease expirations occurring in off-peak months and to drive more leasing volume into peak season where we expect greater pricing power. The increased number of lease expirations will increase frictional vacancy during the second quarter, reducing average daily occupancy by 40 basis points compared to the second quarter 2015 and also increasing turnover expenses. While these costs are expected to be reversed and rewarded in other quarters, in the second quarter, they are expected to reduce year-over-year same-store NOI growth by approximately 100 basis points.
Second, our second quarter expense growth last year was actually negative as a result of nonroutine items in 2015. So while we expect a low expense growth in this year, we also expect faster expense growth in this quarter.
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttext: Nick, it's Keith. I'll take it. Look, let me walk with a broader overview of the objective and then talk about what we did. When we looked at the first and fourth quarter, we believe kind of having 20% of our expiring leases in each of those quarters is where we would like to be and then putting the balance or 60% in the second and third quarters. A year ago, we moved roughly 2,000 units from the shouldering quarters and put them into the second and third quarter, essentially so we could take advantage of peak season and essentially some of the slowdowns that you can see in pricing and demand in particularly November, December, things like that.

componenttext: You got it, Rob. Let me walk through it. I mean, we continue to see recovery and, in fact, acceleration. When we look at our revenue being up 2.4% this past quarter, it was also better sequentially. And really where we sit, we're in suburban Virginia, the Alexandria market and, of course, Maryland. We -- what we've seen is, is that the suburban Virginia outperformed Maryland in this quarter, and more impotently, they did also in the fourth quarter last year, which was the first time we had seen that. So we have 4,000 units. There's a majority of our portfolio in Alexandria area, and it's been outperforming and we're seeing a better performance there.

componenttext: Rob, this is Keith. I'll take it again. One of the things that we have been focused on for many years is matching our staffing levels with the demand of the business. And so we've done this over the years. It's been an area in which we have been able to take advantage of really matching when you have those ebbs and flows. And so what I'd tell you is in January of this year and at the end of last year, when I was getting the team together, we had a very focused effort on -- that the peak season is going to come earlier, how are we going to staff up. And it's not just our own staffing, it's vendors, it's a variety of other folks in which we get well prepared so that we could really take advantage of it and not be in a position that it seems like you're caught off guard but, in fact, it's all by plan and by design.

componenttext: Rich, it's Keith. Let me help you think about it. First of all, there's no cost to it. Essentially, what happens is, is that we have a professional revenue management team that works in-house. And essentially when we're sending out renewal offers, what we're able to do is we're able to stagger and offer different extensions and lengths in order to match up so that we get those leases to get renewed and/or new leases to match up into these new periods of time. So from that standpoint, there's really no difference in the way that cost's associated with it. It's more about just kind of walking through the process and ensuring we match it up that way.

Good afternoon, and welcome to the Aimco First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Lisa Cohn. Please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of w
componenttext:
Thank you. Good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. These statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. Also, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures such as adjusted funds from operations and funds from operations. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website.
Prepared remarks today come from Terry Considine, our Chairman and CEO; Keith Kimmel, our Executive Vice President in charge of property operations; John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer; and Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. A question-and-answer session will follow our prepared remarks.
I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you, and thank you for your interest in Aimco.Business is good. In property operations, same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.1%, the rate of increase 70 basis points better than the 4.4% growth rate of
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you, and thank you for your interest in Aimco.
Business is good. In property operations, same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.1%, the rate of increase 70 basis points better than the 4.4% growth rate of the first quarter last year. Operating expenses were essentially flat. With higher rents and flat expenses, same-store net operating income was up by more than 7%, beating the high end of guidance by 160 basis points, making for a good quarter and a solid start to the year.
In redevelopment, ongoing projects are on time, on budget and are creating value equal to $0.25 to $0.35 for each dollar invested. Patti and her team are doing a great job, including construction on -- completing construction on the south tower and starting construction on the east tower at Park Towne Place in Center City, Philadelphia as well as adding to our active redevelopments by starting the final phase that completes redevelopment of The Sterling in Center City, Philadelphia and starting a second phase at Palazzo at Park La Brea in Los Angeles.
In portfolio management, first quarter revenue per apartment home was up across the entire Aimco portfolio to more than $1,860, an Aimco record and up 9% year-over-year.
For these good results, I offer sincere congratulations and thanks to my Aimco teammates, both here in Denver and across the country. It's a privilege and a pleasure to work with you. I'm especially proud of your grading Aimco a top workplace in Colorado for a fourth consecutive year.
Now for a more detailed report on first quarter operations, I'd like to turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of Property Operations. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. Pleased to report that we had a solid quarter and operations, with revenues up 4.8% year-over-year. Expenses were up 10 basis points year-over-year with net operating income up 7.1% for the quarter. Each of these quarterly metrics are bette
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. Pleased to report that we had a solid quarter and operations, with revenues up 4.8% year-over-year. Expenses were up 10 basis points year-over-year with net operating income up 7.1% for the quarter. Each of these quarterly metrics are better than the first quarter of last year.
In Q1 of 2016, our residents gave us our 10th consecutive quarter better than a 4-star rating in customer satisfaction. This contributed to renewal rent increases of 6% for the quarter, some 120 basis points higher than the first quarter of 2015.
Of note, renewal premiums increased in each successive month of the quarter. We saw particular strength in the Bay Area, Denver and Atlanta. Renewal rents in these markets increased 8% to 9% compared to the expiring leases.
Where those leases expired and were not renewed, our new lease pricing outperformed the results from the first quarter of 2015 and for each month of the quarter individually. This resulted in a quarterly increase in new lease rates of 3.5%, 230 basis points better than last year. The year-over-year rate of growth for new leases was strongest in Boston and Los Angeles.
As a result of our team's hard work, our blended lease rate increases of 4.6% were 180 basis points higher than the first quarter of last year and by 100 basis points sequentially, all while increasing average daily occupancy for the quarter by 10 basis points year-over-year and 50 basis points from fourth quarter.
We had another solid quarter on the expense front, growing by 10 basis points overall and 2% when excluding the year-over-year decline in utility expense due to a milder winter.
Turnover for the quarter was 50.9%. Of the customers who decided to move out, 23% were for career moves, 17% did not renew due to price and 14% moved out to purchase homes. There are no significant changes in these move-out reasons versus recent quarters or our long-term averages.
Our resident quality continues to improve. The average income for those new customers who moved in during the first quarter was $136,000 with a median income of $95,000. Year-over-year, the median income of our new residents was up 19% compared to the first quarter of 2015, with half coming from a more discriminating application process and half from an improvement on our portfolio quality.
Our 12 target markets, which represent 90% of same-store net operating income, had top line revenue growth up 5.2% in the quarter versus 4.8% for the entire portfolio. Our top performers all had revenue increases in double digits from more than 10% to better than 13%. This was led by the Bay Area followed by Seattle and Denver.
Our strong performers, which had revenue growth from nearly 6% to better than 7%, were Boston, San Diego, Atlanta and Greater Los Angeles. Our steady target markets with about 2.5% to 3% revenue growth were Chicago, New York City and Washington, D.C. And finally, with softer revenue growth of around 1%, we had Philadelphia and Miami.
As we look to our April month-to-date results, blended lease rates are up 5%, 10 basis points better than last year. New leases are up 3.6% and renewals are up 6.4%. April's average daily occupancy is at 95.9%, 30 basis points below last year by design.
We've intentionally moved leases from our shoulder months into peak leasing season with higher demand. This improvement in expiration management will pay dividends by repricing leases in periods of greater expected rent growth. And finally, May and June renewal offers went out with 6% to 8% increases.
And with great thanks to our teams in the field and here in Denver for your commitment to Aimco's success, I'll turn the call over to John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer. John?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith, and good day, everybody. Today, I'd like to take a few minutes to review our recent investment and portfolio activities.During the first quarter, we invested $31 million in redevelopment, $9 million of it on our redevelopment pipeline and
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith, and good day, everybody. Today, I'd like to take a few minutes to review our recent investment and portfolio activities.
During the first quarter, we invested $31 million in redevelopment, $9 million of it on our redevelopment pipeline and $22 million at Park Towne Place and The Sterling, both located in Center City, Philadelphia.
At Park Towne Place, we completed redevelopment of the south tower and the town center. 91% of the 224 completed apartment homes in the south tower are leased and rents are ahead of underwriting.
Construction is progressing as planned on the east tower with delivery of the first redeveloped apartment homes coming this summer. Early leasing results are encouraging as we continue to see strong demand.
We also continued our phased redevelopment of The Sterling with 95% of the 283 completed apartment homes leased at rents above underwriting.
Patti and her team continue to plan our next round of redevelopments. And as Terry mentioned, we are continuing that redevelopment at The Sterling and Palazzo, Park La Brea.
At The Sterling, the final phase of redevelopment includes 125 apartment homes on 7 floors and the build-out of the retail space. The incremental cost of this work is approximately $22 million.
We're also moving forward on the continued redevelopment of our Palazzo, Park La Brea property in Los Angeles. This phase will upgrade 389 apartment homes and the accompanying common areas. The incremental investment there is approximately $24 million, with Aimco’s share about $13 million.
During the first quarter, we also invested $16 million in the construction of our One Canal development project in Boston. We anticipate receiving our initial temporary certificate of occupancy for the building within the next few days, and our first move-ins are scheduled for mid-May. To date, 12% of the 310 apartment homes have been leased, and rents there are also above underwriting.
In addition to One Canal, we have 3 other properties that are going lease-up, Axiom, Vivo and Indigo, and we are on track at each. Our lease-up of Axiom and Vivo, the properties that we acquired last year in Cambridge, is progressing well. Axiom, which we acquired in construction completion last April, is now 92% leased; and Vivo, which we completed construction on in October, is 75% leased. Rents and leased space at both properties are exceeding our underwriting.
At Indigo in Redwood City, California, construction continues on plan. We're under contract to purchase this property upon construction completion and anticipate closing the acquisition before our next call. We have commenced leasing at this property and have leased 9% of the 463 apartment homes also at rents in excess of our underwriting.
On the disposition side, we sold 1 Conventional property during the first quarter for $10 million in gross proceeds. We continue to expect to execute the bulk of our property sales in the second and fourth quarters as we match-fund our planned investment activities.
And while we don't normally talk about our sales activity prior to closing, many of you are aware that our buyer on Riverside, Washington REIT, disclosed transaction details on their call yesterday. We can confirm the details as disclosed by them and anticipate closing this transaction during the second quarter. The proceeds from the sale of Riverside will complete the funding of our Indigo acquisition.
And with that, I would now like to turn the call over to Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. Paul?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I will start today with first quarter 2016 results. At $0.51 per share, AFFO was up 11% year-over-year and $0.05 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.57 per share was up 10% year-over-year and $0.03 ahea
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I will start today with first quarter 2016 results. At $0.51 per share, AFFO was up 11% year-over-year and $0.05 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.57 per share was up 10% year-over-year and $0.03 ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. First quarter AFFO outperformance of $0.05 per share was driven by $0.02 from same-store net operating income outperformance, 210 basis points; $0.01 from the timing of income tax-related items; and $0.02 from the timing of capital replacements spending expenditures. With these positive first quarter results, we are increasing full year AFFO and pro forma FFO guidance by $0.01 per share at their respective midpoints. This increase reflects, one, the turnaround of first quarter's $0.03 outperformance related to the timing items I just mentioned; and two, the recognition of $0.01 of the first quarter's $0.02 of same-store NOI outperformance.
I'd like to be clear here, we do not see a slowdown in business compared to our beginning of year expectations. However, we do prefer to take a conservative approach to raising guidance and until we have more visibility into peak leasing season.
On last night's release, we also established second quarter AFFO guidance of $0.45 to $0.49 per share and pro forma FFO guidance of $0.54 to $0.58 per share.
Shifting gears to our operations-related guidance. We're increasing our same-store NOI growth guidance to a range of 5.5% to 6.5%, an increase of 25 basis points at the midpoint. This increase reflects a 75 basis point decrease in projected operating expense growth. Our guidance for full year same-store revenue growth is unchanged at 4.75% at the midpoint.
With last night's release, we also established guidance for second quarter same-store NOI growth of 3.5% to 4.5%, which is consistent with the expectations we had for the quarter when we started the year. Now as then, we expect to see continued solid rent growth with the year-over-year comparison for the quarter affected by 2 items. 
First, as Keith mentioned, we have undertaken to reduce the number of lease expirations occurring in off-peak months and to drive more leasing volume into peak season where we expect greater pricing power. The increased number of lease expirations will increase frictional vacancy during the second quarter, reducing average daily occupancy by 40 basis points compared to the second quarter 2015 and also increasing turnover expenses. While these costs are expected to be reversed and rewarded in other quarters, in the second quarter, they are expected to reduce year-over-year same-store NOI growth by approximately 100 basis points.
Second, our second quarter expense growth last year was actually negative as a result of nonroutine items in 2015. So while we expect a low expense growth in this year, we also expect faster expense growth in this quarter.
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. [Operator Instructions] Operator, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Just want to start on the shifting of the leases and the lease optimization. What drove the decision to do that this year? And will it be complete in terms of the allocation for each quarter to where you would like to see it after 2016?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nick, it's Keith Kimmel. I'll take it. Look, let me walk with a broader overview of the objective and then talk about what we did. When we looked at the first and fourth quarter, we believe kind of having 20% of our expiring leases in each of those quarte
componenttext: Nick, it's Keith Kimmel. I'll take it. Look, let me walk with a broader overview of the objective and then talk about what we did. When we looked at the first and fourth quarter, we believe kind of having 20% of our expiring leases in each of those quarters is where we would like to be and then putting the balance or 60% in the second and third quarters. A year ago, we moved roughly 2,000 units from the shouldering quarters and put them into the second and third quarter, essentially so we could take advantage of peak season and essentially some of the slowdowns that you can see in pricing and demand in particularly November, December, things like that.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Nick, this is Terry. And there's -- 10% of our portfolio is in the bottom 10%. So it's a question of -- for what's noncore, it's a question of what the use of proceeds would be. So that's a little bit difficult to describe specifically. There are no assets that we own that we don't appreciate owning and there's no assets that we own that in time won’t be ready for sale. The second question about special dividends is one that we have focused on and discussed with our largest shareholders. And our view is that they want us to continue to be invested in the apartment business. We serve an allocation for them and what they expect is us to focus on running apartments, collecting the rent and cutting the grass.

componenttext: Sure. Nick, let me walk through -- there's a couple of unique things in those 3. In the Bay Area, we have a single building that outperformed. It's the Pacific Bay Vistas, our redevelopment that we did a few years back that is extremely well located and has really done well. And then the third is Chicago, in which both our As and Bs are almost on top of each other. Our As just nudged them out probably about 10 basis points. So very, very close.

And since all the units are available and ready to be leased, there's no capitalization of costs other than what you would typically capitalize on an operating property to the extent there's construction activities.

But the Miami numbers are influenced in very specific cases our 3 largest properties there, which are Flamingo, Yacht Club and Bay Parc, each have a nearby adjacent construction disruptions of one degree or another and it's not necessarily representative of the market.

componenttext: So Jana, thanks for that question. It's something that we do on a regular basis. It's -- over the past many years, it's something we review. We know that at the end of the day that we have a responsibility, that we help pick the neighbors that live in our communities and we want to take a more concerted effort to even push further.

We -- what we've seen is, is that the suburban Virginia outperformed Maryland in this quarter, and more importantly, it did it also in the fourth quarter last year, which was the first time we had seen that.
