componenttext: Rob, this is Keith. I'll take it again. One of the things that we have been focused on for many years is matching our staffing levels with the demand of the business. And so we've done this over the years. It's been an area in which we have been able to take advantage of really matching when you have those ebbs and flows. And so what I'd tell you is in January of this year and at the end of last year, when I was getting the team together, we had a very focused effort on -- that the peak season is going to come earlier, how are we going to staff up. And it's not just our own staffing, it's vendors, it's a variety of other folks in which we get well prepared so that we could really take advantage of it and not be in a position that it seems like you're caught off guard but, in fact, it's all by plan and by design.

componenttext: So you mentioned -- on the lease optimization process, is there any cost to that in terms of making a deal with people or whatever to shift into the second, third quarter? And is there any more of it to do?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Rich, it's Keith. Let me help you think about it. First of all, there's no cost to it. Essentially, what happens is, is that we have a professional revenue management team that works in-house. And essentially when we're sending out renewal offers, what we
componenttext: Rich, it's Keith. Let me help you think about it. First of all, there's no cost to it. Essentially, what happens is, is that we have a professional revenue management team that works in-house. And essentially when we're sending out renewal offers, what we're able to do is we're able to stagger and offer different extensions and lengths in order to match up so that we get those leases to get renewed and/or new leases to match up into these new periods of time. So from that standpoint, there's really no difference in the way that cost's associated with it. It's more about just kind of walking through the process and ensuring we match it up that way.

componenttext: And then just I got a quick question, a follow-up question unrelated. I'm curious how you feel about that. And are you -- do you have an eye towards Philly becoming a better -- a much better market? Is that why you're developing there? componenttext: Rich, this is Keith, I'll take a first at it and then I can ask John or Terry or if anyone else wants to add in. In fact, when we look at the redevelopments that we're doing at Park Towne and Sterling in Center City, there's not anything that's better located than those buildings in all of Philadelphia. And in fact, those are being received and leased up above our expectation. And I would just tell you that we would not change the way we're thinking about that in any way. John?

componenttext: Just to double down on a little bit, if you recall our conversation back in October at the Investor Day, Philadelphia, for us, long term in the portfolio is Center City. We have high hopes and high prospects for Center City.

componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome to the Aimco Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President, General Counsel. Please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. Statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of whi
componenttext:
Thank you, and good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. Statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found on our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today. 
We'll also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as AFFO and FFO. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website. 
Prepared remarks today come from Terry Considine, at Chairman and CEO; Keith Kimmel, Executive Vice President in Charge of Property Operations; John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer; and Paul Beldin, Chief Financial Officer. A question-and-answer session will follow our prepared remarks. 
I will now turn the call over to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you. We appreciate your interest in Aimco. Aimco portfolio diversification across markets and price points is serving us well. Business remains good and on plan, notwithstanding the predictable ebb and flow of v
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you. We appreciate your interest in Aimco. Aimco portfolio diversification across markets and price points is serving us well. Business remains good and on plan, notwithstanding the predictable ebb and flow of various local markets. We hear a lot of questions about the direction of apartment markets. Are markets accelerating based on demographic demand? Or are they decelerating under the pressure of new supply? We believe that both questions can be answered with a yes. On the one hand, demographic demand is historically strong, predictably so and will be strengthened for many years to come by baby boomers increasing their preference for rental housing. On the other hand, all markets will be overbuilt at some point, meaning that competitive new supply will limit or even reverse rent growth, but not all markets will be overbuilt at the same time, and where there is oversupply, it will have its greatest impact on properties with the highest rents. And that's why we emphasize diversification by market and by price point as the foundation of Aimco portfolio strategy. The nature of a diversified portfolio is that there are generally some markets accelerating and some decelerating, that's true for Aimco today, as Keith will discussed further in his remarks. We expect that portfolio diversification will make Aimco revenue more predictable and less volatile. 
Here are 4 headlines for the Aimco's second quarter:
First, Property Operations are on track. Same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.3%, a rate of increase 100 basis points greater than in the same quarter 1 year ago. After increased frictional vacancy due to transferring lease expirations from our shoulder quarters to our leasing season, that contributed about a 20% increase in lease expirations in the second quarter. And after reduced utility reimbursements due to milder weather and lower energy costs, same-store revenue was up 4.2% year-over-year. These results are consistent with our plan, and given outperformance in the first quarter, make us confident that we will meet our same-store guidance for the full year, which you will recall, we increased at the end of the first quarter. I'm also delighted to report that Keith and his team are on track with lease up efforts at One Canal in Boston and Indigo in Redwood City. 
Second headline. Redevelopment value creation continues. Current redevelopment projects are on track to create value comfortably in excess of our benchmark expectation, that each $1 redevelopment spending will become worth $1.30 or more. Work continues on 2 multiyear projects in Center City, Philadelphia and construction started on the next phase of redevelopment of The Palazzo in Los Angeles. In Boston, we have substantially completed construction of One Canal. 
Our third headline. Aimco portfolio quality reaches a new high. In portfolio management, we continue to sell our lowest rated properties and reinvest the proceeds and properties with higher rents and better prospects. Second quarter revenue per apartment home across the entire Aimco portfolio increased by 8% year-over-year to a new record $1,900 a month. 
And fourth headline. Aimco beat guidance for the second quarter and raised its guidance for the full year, just as we did following the first quarter. 
For these good results, I offer sincere thanks to my Aimco teammates, here in Denver as well as across the country. It's a privilege and a pleasure to work with you. 
And now, for a more detailed report on second quarter operations, I'd like to turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of Property Operations. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. As previously discussed, we succeeded in moving 1,200 of our lease expirations out of the softer shoulder months and into the stronger second quarter. Our strategy increased our total second quarter expirations by design by roughly 20%. Thi
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. As previously discussed, we succeeded in moving 1,200 of our lease expirations out of the softer shoulder months and into the stronger second quarter. Our strategy increased our total second quarter expirations by design by roughly 20%. This was executed so that we have greater revenue growth opportunity in the long term and seasonably higher demand periods at significantly improved rates, understanding the frictional vacancy would increase in the short term. 
Operationally, we navigated through those additional expiring leases while staying on plan. We delivered rent growth of 5.3% and revenue growth of 4.2% year-over-year. Expenses, less taxes and insurance, were up 2.3%. We feel good about our strategy and the ability to deliver our revenue commitment for the balance of the year. 
While we've seen supply pressure in places like Miami, Los Angeles, and to a lesser extent, the Bay Area, we enjoy the benefit of a diversified portfolio from both the geographic perspective and at varying price points. The benefit of this, while some markets moderated, our second quarter results were aided by accelerating markets, including Washington DC, Boston and Chicago. Our 12 markets comprised about 90% of our same-store revenues. Using blended lease rate growth for the quarter, roughly 45% of our target markets accelerated, 45% decelerated, with the remainder about flat on a weighted basis. 
In the second quarter of 2016, our residents gave us our 11th consecutive quarter of better than a 4-star rating in customer satisfaction. This contributed to our renewal rent increases of 6.2% for the quarter, some 110 basis points higher than the second quarter of 2015. We saw particular strength in Seattle, the Bay Area and Denver. Renewal rents in these markets increased between 9% and 14% compared to the expiring leases. While those leases expired and were not renewed, our new lease pricing accelerated in each successive month of the quarter. This resulted in a quarterly increase in new lease rates of 4.4%. The year-over-year rate of growth for new leases was strongest in Seattle, Boston, San Diego and the Bay Area, ranging between 8% and 19%. 
As a result of our team's hard work, our blended lease rate increases of 5.3% were 70 basis points higher than the first quarter of this year, all while maintaining a relatively flat average daily occupancy. Turnover for the quarter was better year-over-year at 49.3%, despite the significant increase in expiring leases. Of the customers who decided to move out, 26% were for career moves, 19% did not renew due to price and 15% moved out to purchase homes. There are no significant changes in these moveout reasons versus recent quarters or our long-term averages. 
Our resident quality continues to improve. The average incomes of those new customers who moved in during the second quarter was $140,000 with a median income of $95,000. Year-over-year, the median income of our new residents was up 6% compared to the second quarter of 2015. 
Our 12 target markets had revenue growth up 4.5% in the second quarter versus 4.2% for the entire portfolio. Our top performers had revenue increases from more than 8% to better than 11%. This was led by the Bay Area, followed by Seattle, Denver and Atlanta. Our strong performance, which had revenue growth from almost 5% to better than 6% were San Diego, Boston, New York and greater Los Angeles. Our steady target markets with about 2% to 3% revenue growth were Chicago, Washington DC and Philadelphia. And, finally, pushing out about flat year-over-year, we had Miami. 
While not yet complete, our July month to date results have blended lease rates up 4.9%. New leases up 4% and renewals up 5.8%. July's average daily occupancy is at 95.4%, roughly equal to that of July of 2015, despite having 300 more expiring leases year-over-year, we're intentionally moved leases from our shoulder months into peak leasing season. And finally, August and September renewal offers went out with 6% to 8% increases. 
And with great thanks to our teams in the field and here in Denver for your commitment to Aimco's success, I'll turn the call over to John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer. John?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. During the second quarter, we continued to focus our investment activities on upgrading our portfolio through redevelopment development and other capital investments. We invested $43 million in redevelopment, $31 million in Park Towne Pl
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. During the second quarter, we continued to focus our investment activities on upgrading our portfolio through redevelopment development and other capital investments. We invested $43 million in redevelopment, $31 million in Park Towne Place in Sterling and Philadelphia and an additional $12 million in several smaller projects and our redevelopment pipeline. 
At Park Towne Place, we achieved stabilized occupancy at the recently completed South Tower. We are making good progress in construction on the East Tower, which is now 70 47% leased. And with these successes, we approved spending another $41 million to redevelop the North Tower. 
We also continued our phased redevelopment in The Sterling. Of the 409 completed apartment homes, 81% are leased, and rents are above underwriting. During the second quarter, Aimco approved the final phase of redevelopment of The Sterling, which includes the remaining 125 apartment homes, commercial and retail buildout and completion of the streetscape. The estimated investment for this final phase is $22 million. 
Also during the second quarter, Aimco approved the next phase of redevelopment of The Palazzo, a 521 home community located in the mid-Wilshire district of Los Angeles. This next phase includes the renovation of 389 apartment homes on the first 3 floors of the community. Construction started in June and is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2018. The Palazzo is owned through a joint venture in which Aimco has an approximate 53% interest. The total estimated investment in this phase is $25 million, of which Aimco shares $13 million. 
During the second quarter, we also invested $13 million in the construction of our One Canal development project in Boston. As Terry mentioned, construction is largely complete, with just a few finishing touches in progress. Our first residents moved in mid-May and 41% of the apartment homes are currently leased at rents above underwriting. 100% of the commercial space at One Canal is leased by a single retail tenant within the process of obtaining the required permits. 
In addition to One Canal, we have 3 other properties at varying stages of lease up, Indigo, Axiom and Vivo. At Indigo, in Redwood City California, the developers secured the TCO for the property in late June and the first residents moved in July 1. The property is 21% leased today and went ahead of our underwriting. We will purchase the property upon construction completion which we anticipate will occur by the end of the third quarter. 
Our lease up of Axiom and Vivo, the properties we acquired last year in Kendall Square in Cambridge are now complete. Those properties reached 95% occupancy earlier this month, with rents and leased space both better than our initial underwriting. 
On the disposition side of the business, the market remains robust. In accordance with plan, we sold 2 Conventional properties during the second quarter for $292 million in gross proceeds, and we expect to meet our disposition guidance for the year. Revenues per apartment home for the property sold in the second quarter averaged just over $1,500, about 20% below the average of our retained portfolio. 
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. Paul?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Starting with second quarter 2016 results, at $0.50 per share, AFFO was up 9% year-over-year and $0.03 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO at $0.59 per share was up 5% year-over-year and was also $0.03 per sh
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Starting with second quarter 2016 results, at $0.50 per share, AFFO was up 9% year-over-year and $0.03 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO at $0.59 per share was up 5% year-over-year and was also $0.03 per share above the midpoint of guidance. Second quarter AFFO outperformance was driven by a greater than planned noncore earnings, including $0.01 related to a transaction that was originally expected to occur in the fourth quarter. 
Turning to the balance sheet. The property debt market remains deep and liquid. During the quarter, we took advantage of declining treasury rates and compressing spreads, pricing 2 fixed rate amortizing, nonrecourse property loans with 10 year terms. The first for $145 million, priced at a spread to treasuries of approximately 150 basis points with an all in interest rate of 3.34%. 
The second were $21.5 million, priced at a spread of 129 basis points for an all in rate of 2.77%. 
Additionally, we reduced our overall cost of leverage by redeeming today our 7% series Z issue of preferred stock. We are well positioned to take advantage of today's uncertain interest rate environment. If interest rates remain low, earnings will benefit as we refinance maturities with weighted average interest rates of approximately 5% at expected lower rates. If rates increase, our long-duration fixed-rate debt, with a 7.8-year weighted average maturity, will mitigate the financial impact and provide a hedge should cap rates rise. 
Now, looking forward to the remainder of the year. We're increasing full year pro forma FFO and AFFO guidance for the $0.02 of non-timing related second quarter outperformance, offset by $0.01 reduction due to the decision to vacate the North Tower at Park Towne Place as we accelerate its redevelopment time line. 
After our second guidance raise this year, full year AFFO and pro forma FFO guidance is now $0.02 per share higher than our expectation at the beginning of the year. 
In yesterday's release, we also established third quarter AFFO guidance of $0.43 to $0.47 per share and pro forma FFO guidance of $0.52 to $0.56 per share. 
Shifting gears to operational guidance. With second quarter results meeting our expectations and a consistent outlook for the remainder of the year, our expectation of same-store revenue growth of 4.5% to 5% remains unchanged. Underpinning our guidance at the midpoint is an expectation of 5% revenue growth in the second half of 2016. With strong rate growth already embedded in our in place leases and expectations for continued above trend demand, 5% revenue growth appears to be achievable. 
We also confirmed our expectation of 1.75% to 2.25% expense growth and NOI growth of 5.5% to 6.5% for the full year. With this release, we also established guidance for the third quarter same-store NOI growth of 5.5% to 6.5% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. This is in line with the expectations we have for the quarter at the start of the year. 
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. Please limit your questions to 2 per time the queue. Laura, turn it over to you for the first question.

componenttextpreview: Austin, this is John. Couple of things related to timing. The developer and the contractor just ran a little slower than what initially they thought there going to for delivery. As we noted in my comments, they got TCO on the units of the building or part
componenttext: Austin, this is John. Couple of things related to timing. The developer and the contractor just ran a little slower than what initially they thought there going to for delivery. As we noted in my comments, they got TCO on the units of the building or partial TCO for the finished units at the building at the end of June. First occupancies first move-ins were literally July 1. We have, today, accepted about 1/3 of the units in the building. So it's still an active construction. So the amenities were mostly completed about a week ago, but they're not all done. We're not in the leasing office yet. And so this is still a building very much under construction. And so between leasing pace and tightening of closing, really, this is driven by the completion of the building, which we anticipate will occur again some time before the end of the quarter, this third quarter.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, you talked about the guidance assuming 5% same-store revenue growth in the back half, which is acceleration from the first half, which is different than what peers are seeing. So I'm wondering if you can walk through the occupancy rent in other inco
componenttext: Paul, you talked about the guidance assuming 5% same-store revenue growth in the back half, which is acceleration from the first half, which is different than what peers are seeing. So I'm wondering if you can walk through the occupancy rent in other income assumptions embedded in that guidance.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet, Nick. I'd be happy to. As you all know, our ability to grow revenue is dependent upon 3, 3 factors. First, as you're asking your question, Nick, is occupancy. The second impact relates to the revenue growth that's already embedded in our rent rol
componenttext: You bet, Nick. I'd be happy to. As you all know, our ability to grow revenue is dependent upon 3, 3 factors. First, as you're asking your question, Nick, is occupancy. The second impact relates to the revenue growth that's already embedded in our rent roll today. And the third is the impact of new and renewable leases that are transacted during the second half of the year. And so as we think about occupancy growth, in the third quarter, we expect that occupancy will be fairly similar to 2015, but because of the positive impact that we expect to see from our lease expiration management, we expect a bump-up in occupancy in the fourth quarter. Then the second factor I mentioned is the growth embedded in our rent roll. Within our rent roll today, we probably have about 75% to 80% of our revenue baked in for the second half of the year. And those -- that amount that's baked in is at a rate that's right around 5%. And so then the last major component relates to the transacted rate that we expect to see for the second half of the year. And so in order to hit the midpoint of our guidance, we'd have to see transacted rates probably in the mid-to upper 4 ranges. And so based upon a 5% transacted rate growth year-to-date, that seems to be quite achievable.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttextpreview: As we look at our expectations for other income at the start of the year, we thought that other income would grow in about the 3% range versus the 4% where we were in 2015. What we've seen through the first half of the year is other income has grown much
componenttext: As we look at our expectations for other income at the start of the year, we thought that other income would grow in about the 3% range versus the 4% where we were in 2015. What we've seen through the first half of the year is other income has grown much more slowly, I think we're up less than 100 basis points. That is largely attributable to lower utility expenses. And so while we don't know what's going to happen for the remainder of the year, we are able to be reimbursed for about 65% of our utility costs. So whether utilities are up or down, the impact on NOI is rather nominal.

componenttext: Yes. John, you're exactly right. The delay in the acquisition of Indigo will be a net positive for Aimco, not only from a 2016 economic endpoint, but more importantly, from an IRR standpoint. Because as we underwrote the project, we expected the building to be completely empty on day 1. And so now, when we take it over, it'll be at least partially, partially leased, and we'll have income coming in from day 1. Now unfortunately for us, there is not a real significant benefit to us in 2016. We pick up probably a few hundred thousand dollars from this delay on a bottom line basis. So it's not necessarily impactful for 2016 results.

Good afternoon, and welcome to the Aimco Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Lisa Cohn, Executive Vice President, General Counsel. Please go ahead.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. Statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of whi
componenttext:
Thank you, and good day. During this conference call, the forward-looking statements we make are based on management's judgment, including projections related to 2016 results. Statements are subject to certain risks and uncertainties, a description of which can be found in our SEC filings. Actual results may differ materially from what may be discussed today.
We will also discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures, such as AFFO and FFO. These are defined and are reconciled to the most comparable GAAP measures in the supplemental information that is part of the full earnings release published on Aimco's website.
Prepared remarks today come from Terry Considine, Chairman and CEO; Keith Kimmel, Executive Vice President in Charge of Property Operations; John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer; and Paul Beldin, Chief Financial Officer.
A question-and-answer session will follow our prepared remarks.
I will now turn the call to Terry Considine. Terry?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you. We appreciate your interest in Aimco. Aimco portfolio diversification across markets and price points is serving us well. Business remains good and on plan, notwithstanding the predictable ebb and flow of v
componenttext:
Thank you, Lisa, and good morning to all of you. We appreciate your interest in Aimco. Aimco portfolio diversification across markets and price points is serving us well. Business remains good and on plan, notwithstanding the predictable ebb and flow of various local markets. We hear a lot of questions about the direction of apartment markets. Are markets accelerating based on demographic demand? Or are they decelerating under the pressure of new supply? We believe that both questions can be answered with a yes. On the one hand, demographic demand is historically strong, predictably so, and will be strengthened for many years to come by baby boomers increasing their preference for rental housing. On the other hand, all markets will be overbuilt at some point, meaning that competitive new supply will limit or even reverse rent growth, but not all markets will be overbuilt at the same time, and where there is oversupply, it will have its greatest impact on properties with the highest rents. And that's why we emphasize diversification by market and by price point as the foundation of the Aimco portfolio strategy. The nature of a diversified portfolio is that there are generally some markets accelerating and some decelerating. That's true for Aimco today, as Keith will discuss further in his remarks. We expect that portfolio diversification will make Aimco revenue more predictable and less volatile.
Here are 4 headlines for the Aimco's second quarter:
first, property operations are on track. Same-store rent per apartment home was up 5.3%, a rate of increase 100 basis points greater than in the same quarter 1 year ago. After increased frictional vacancy due to transferring lease expirations from our shoulder quarters to our leasing season, that contributed about a 20% increase in lease expirations in the second quarter. And after reduced utility reimbursements due to milder weather and lower energy costs, same-store revenue was up 4.2% year-over-year. These results are consistent with our plan, and given outperformance in the first quarter, make us confident that we will meet our same-store guidance for the full year, which, you will recall, we increased at the end of the first quarter. I'm also delighted to report that Keith and his team are on track with lease-up efforts at One Canal in Boston and Indigo in Redwood City.
Second headline. Redevelopment and value creation continues. Current redevelopment projects are on track to create value comfortably in excess of our benchmark expectation that each $1 redevelopment spending will become worth $1.30 or more. Work continues on 2 multiyear projects in Center City, Philadelphia and construction started on the next phase of redevelopment at the Palazzo in Los Angeles. In Boston, we have substantially completed construction of One Canal.
Our third headline. Aimco portfolio quality reaches a new high. In portfolio management, we continue to sell our lowest rated properties and reinvest the proceeds and properties with higher rents and better prospects. Second quarter revenue per apartment home across the entire Aimco portfolio increased by 8% year-over-year to a new record $1,900 a month.
And the fourth headline. Aimco beat guidance for the second quarter and raised its guidance for the full year, just as we did following the first quarter.
For these good results, I offer sincere thanks to my Aimco teammates, both here in Denver as well as across the country. It's a privilege and a pleasure to work with you.
And now for a more detailed report on second quarter operations, I'd like to turn the call over to Keith Kimmel, Head of Property Operations. Keith?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terry. As previously discussed, we succeeded in moving 1,200 of our lease expirations out of the softer shoulder months and into the stronger second quarter. Our strategy increased our total second quarter expirations by design by roughly 20%. Thi
componenttext:
Thanks, Terry. As previously discussed, we succeeded in moving 1,200 of our lease expirations out of the softer shoulder months and into the stronger second quarter. Our strategy increased our total second quarter expirations by design by roughly 20%. This was executed so that we have greater revenue growth opportunity in the long term and seasonably higher demand periods at significantly improved rates, understanding the frictional vacancy would increase in the short term.
Operationally, we navigated through those additional expiring leases while staying on plan. We delivered rent growth of 5.3% and revenue growth of 4.2% year-over-year. Expenses, less taxes and insurance, were up 2.3%. We feel good about our strategy and the ability to deliver our revenue commitment for the balance of the year.
While we've seen supply pressure in places like Miami, Los Angeles and to a lesser extent, the Bay Area, we enjoy the benefit of a diversified portfolio from both a geographic perspective and at varying price points. The benefit of this, while some markets moderated, our second quarter results were aided by accelerating markets, including Washington DC, Boston and Chicago. Our 12 target markets comprise about 90% of our same-store revenues. Using blended lease rate growth for the quarter, roughly 45% of our target markets accelerated, 45% decelerated, with the remainder about flat on a weighted basis.
In the second quarter of 2016, our residents gave us our 11th consecutive quarter of better than a 4-star rating in customer satisfaction. This contributed to our renewal rent increases of 6.2% for the quarter, some 110 basis points higher than the second quarter of 2015. We saw particular strength in Seattle, the Bay Area and Denver. Renewal rents in these markets increased between 9% and 14% compared to the expiring leases. While those leases expired and were not renewed, our new lease pricing accelerated in each successive month of the quarter. This resulted in quarterly increase in new lease rates of 4.4%. The year-over-year rate of growth for new leases was strongest in Seattle, Boston, San Diego and the Bay Area, ranging between 8% and 19%.
As a result of our team's hard work, our blended lease rate increases of 5.3% were 70 basis points higher than the first quarter of this year, all while maintaining a relatively flat average daily occupancy. Turnover for the quarter was better year-over-year at 49.3%, despite the significant increase in expiring leases. Of the customers who decided to move out, 26% were for career moves, 19% did not renew due to price and 15% moved out to purchase homes. There are no significant changes in these moveout reasons versus recent quarters or our long-term averages.
Our resident quality continues to improve. The average incomes of those new customers who moved in during the second quarter was $140,000 with a median income of $95,000. Year-over-year, the median income of our new residents was up 6% compared to the second quarter of 2015.
Our 12 target markets had revenue growth up 4.5% in the second quarter versus 4.2% for the entire portfolio. Our top performers had revenue increases from more than 8% to better than 11%. This was led by the Bay Area, followed by Seattle, Denver and Atlanta. Our strong performers, which had revenue growth from almost 5% to better than 6%, were San Diego, Boston, New York and Greater Los Angeles. Our steady target markets with about 2% to 3% revenue growth were Chicago, Washington DC and Philadelphia. And finally, pushing out about flat year-over-year, we had Miami.
While not yet complete, our July month-to-date results had blended lease rates up 4.9%, new leases up 4% and renewals up 5.8%. July's average daily occupancy is at 95.4%, roughly equal to that of July of 2015, despite having 300 more expiring leases year-over-year where we intentionally move leases from our shoulder months and into peak leasing season. And finally, August and September renewal offers went out with 6% to 8% increases.
And with great thanks to our teams in the field and here in Denver for your commitment to Aimco's success, I'll turn the call over to John Bezzant, our Chief Investment Officer. John?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Keith. During the second quarter, we continued to focus our investment activities on upgrading our portfolio through redevelopment, development and other capital investments. We invested $43 million in redevelopment, $31 million in added Park T
componenttext:
Thank you, Keith. During the second quarter, we continued to focus our investment activities on upgrading our portfolio through redevelopment, development and other capital investments. We invested $43 million in redevelopment, $31 million in added Park Towne Place and The Sterling in Philadelphia and an additional $12 million in several smaller projects and/or redevelopment pipeline.
At Park Towne Place, we achieved stabilized occupancy at the recently completed South Tower. We're making good progress in construction on the East Tower, which is now 70 -- 47% leased. And with these successes, we approved spending another $41 million to redevelop the North Tower.
We also continued our phased redevelopment of The Sterling. Of the 409 completed apartment homes, 81% are leased and rents are above underwriting. During the second quarter, Aimco approved the final phase of redevelopment of The Sterling, which includes the remaining 125 apartment homes, commercial and retail buildout and completion of the streetscape. The estimated investment for this final phase is $22 million.
Also during the second quarter, Aimco approved the next phase of redevelopment of The Palazzo, a 521 home community located in the Mid-Wilshire district of Los Angeles. This next phase includes the renovation of 389 apartment homes on the first 3 floors of the community. Construction started in June and is expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2018. The Palazzo is owned through a joint venture in which Aimco has an approximate 53% interest. The total estimated investment in this phase is $25 million, of which Aimco shares $13 million.
During the second quarter, we also invested $13 million in the construction of our One Canal development project in Boston. As Terry mentioned, construction is largely complete with just a few finishing touches in progress. Our first residents moved in mid-May, and 41% of the apartment homes are currently leased at rents above underwriting. And 100% of the commercial space at One Canal is leased by a single retail tenant who is in the process of obtaining the required permits.
In addition to One Canal, we have 3 other properties at varying stages of lease-up, Indigo, Axiom and Vivo. At Indigo, in Redwood City California, the developers secured the TCO for the property in late June and the first residents moved in July 1. The property is 21% leased today at rents ahead of our underwriting. We will purchase the property upon construction completion, which we anticipate will occur by the end of the third quarter.
Our lease-ups of Axiom and Vivo, the properties we acquired last year in Kendall Square in Cambridge, are now complete. Both properties reached 95% occupancy earlier this month with rents and leased space both better than our initial underwriting.
On the disposition side of the business, the market remains robust. In accordance with plan, we sold 2 Conventional properties during the second quarter for $292 million in gross proceeds, and we expect to meet our dispositions guidance for the year. Revenues per apartment home for the property sold in the second quarter averaged just over $1,500, about 20% below the average of our retained portfolio.
And with that, I'd like to turn the call over to Paul Beldin, our Chief Financial Officer. Paul?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Starting with second quarter 2016 results. At $0.50 per share, AFFO was up 9% year-over-year and $0.03 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.59 per share was up 5% year-over-year and was also $0.03 per sh
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Starting with second quarter 2016 results. At $0.50 per share, AFFO was up 9% year-over-year and $0.03 per share ahead of the midpoint of our guidance range. Pro forma FFO of $0.59 per share was up 5% year-over-year and was also $0.03 per share above the midpoint of guidance. Second quarter AFFO outperformance was driven by a greater than planned noncore earnings, including $0.01 related to a transaction that was originally expected to occur in the fourth quarter.
Turning to the balance sheet. The property debt market remains deep and liquid. During the quarter, we took advantage of declining treasury rates and compressing spreads, pricing 2 fixed rate amortizing, nonrecourse property loans with 10-year terms. The first for $145 million, priced at a spread to treasuries of approximately 150 basis points with an all in interest rate of 3.34%. The second for $21.5 million, priced at a spread of 129 basis points for an all in rate of 2.77%.
Additionally, we reduced our overall cost of leverage by redeeming today our 7% series Z issue of preferred stock. We are well positioned to take advantage of today's uncertain interest rate environment. If interest rates remain low, earnings will benefit as we refinance maturities with weighted average interest rates of approximately 5% at expected lower rates. If rates increase, our long-duration fixed-rate debt with a 7.8-year weighted average maturity will mitigate the financial impact and provide a hedge should cap rates rise.
Now looking forward to the remainder of the year. We're increasing full year pro forma FFO and AFFO guidance for the $0.02 of non-timing related second quarter outperformance, offset by $0.01 reduction due to the decision to vacate the North Tower at Park Towne Place as we accelerate its redevelopment time line.
After our second guidance raise this year, full year AFFO and pro forma FFO guidance is now $0.02 per share higher than our expectation at the beginning of the year.
In yesterday's release, we also established third quarter AFFO guidance of $0.43 to $0.47 per share and pro forma FFO guidance of $0.52 to $0.56 per share.
Shifting gears to operational guidance. With second quarter results meeting our expectations and a consistent outlook for the remainder of the year, our expectation of same-store revenue growth of 4.5% to 5% remains unchanged. Underpinning our guidance at the midpoint is an expectation of 5% revenue growth in the second half of 2016. With strong rent growth already embedded in our in-place leases and expectations for continued above trend demand, 5% revenue growth appears to be achievable.
We also confirmed our expectation of 1.75% to 2.25% expense growth and NOI growth of 5.5% to 6.5% for the full year. With yesterday's release, we also established guidance for third quarter same-store NOI growth of 5.5% to 6.5% when compared to the third quarter of 2015. This is in line with the expectations we had for the quarter at the start of the year.
With that, we will now open up the call for questions. [Operator Instructions] Laura, I'll turn it over to you for the first question.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Jordan Sadler of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And the first question comes from Jordan Sadler of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just first question on LA. It softened a bit this quarter, but appeared to be largely occupancy-driven. So I was just curious if any of that was related to the revenue optimization initiatives, the moving of the le
componenttext: It's Austin Wurschmidt here with Jordan. Just first question on LA. It softened a bit this quarter, but appeared to be largely occupancy-driven. So I was just curious if any of that was related to the revenue optimization initiatives, the moving of the leases or if that's the effects you're feeling from new supply?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Austin, it's Keith. I'll take it. You're spot on, on both cases, actually. So about a percent of it was associated with leases that we had moved from shorter months into the second quarter, about 100 leases again, about a percent of frictional vacancy. Th
componenttext: Austin, it's Keith. I'll take it. You're spot on, on both cases, actually. So about a percent of it was associated with leases that we had moved from shorter months into the second quarter, about 100 leases again, about a percent of frictional vacancy. The second piece is that we are seeing some new supply in Los Angeles, about 2,500 units, but in more particular, about 600 in the Mid-Wilshire district where the majority of our apartments are. So we're working through that, but those are the 2 components.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just following up on the first one. What's your expectation then for LA in sort of the back half of the year? I think you have another difficult occupancy comp in the third quarter.
componenttext: So just following up on the first one. What's your expectation then for LA in sort of the back half of the year? I think you have another difficult occupancy comp in the third quarter.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Austin, we'll continue to work through it through July, August and September, and then we will see accelerations beginning through the fourth quarter where [indiscernible] the lease is out of.
componenttext: So Austin, we'll continue to work through it through July, August and September, and then we will see accelerations beginning through the fourth quarter where [indiscernible] the lease is out of.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just second question on the Indigo project. Last quarter, you talked about closing that ahead of this call. I was wondering if there was anything specific as to why that was pushed back a little bit later. And then separately, just on the l
componenttext: Okay. And then just second question on the Indigo project. Last quarter, you talked about closing that ahead of this call. I was wondering if there was anything specific as to why that was pushed back a little bit later. And then separately, just on the lease up pace, I guess what units are available? You're about 5% as of the end of 1Q, just over 20% here today. I mean, would you expect that to accelerate? I mean, are you guys showing -- actually showing available units at this point?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Austin, this is John. A couple of things relating to timing. The developer and the contractor just ran a little slower than what they initially thought they were going to for delivery. As we noted in my comments, they got TCO on the units of the buil
componenttext: Yes. Austin, this is John. A couple of things relating to timing. The developer and the contractor just ran a little slower than what they initially thought they were going to for delivery. As we noted in my comments, they got TCO on the units of the building -- or partial TCO for the finished units of the building at the end of June. First occupancies -- first move-ins were literally July 1. We have, today, accepted about 1/3 of the units in the building. So it's still an active construction zone. The amenities were mostly completed about a week ago, but they're not all done. We're not in the leasing office yet. And so this is still a building very much under construction. And so between leasing pace and timing of closing, really, this is driven by the completion of the building, which we anticipate will occur again some time before the end of the quarter -- this third quarter.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Nick Joseph of Citigroup.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Nick Joseph of Citigroup.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, you talked about the guidance assuming 5% same-store revenue growth in the back half, which is an acceleration from the first half, which is different than what peers are seeing. So I'm wondering if you can walk through the occupancy rent and other
componenttext: Paul, you talked about the guidance assuming 5% same-store revenue growth in the back half, which is an acceleration from the first half, which is different than what peers are seeing. So I'm wondering if you can walk through the occupancy rent and other income assumptions embedded in that guidance?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: You bet, Nick, I'd be happy to. As you all know, our ability to grow revenue is dependent upon 3 factors. First, as you asked in your question, Nick, is occupancy. The second impact relates to the revenue growth that's already embedded in our rent roll to
componenttext: You bet, Nick, I'd be happy to. As you all know, our ability to grow revenue is dependent upon 3 factors. First, as you asked in your question, Nick, is occupancy. The second impact relates to the revenue growth that's already embedded in our rent roll today. And the third is the impact of new and renewable leases that are transacted during the second half of the year. And so as we think about occupancy growth, in the third quarter, we expect that occupancy will be fairly similar to 2015, but because of the positive impact that we expect to see from our lease expiration management, we expect a bump-up in occupancy in the fourth quarter. Then -- the second factor I mentioned is the growth embedded in our rent roll. Within our rent roll today, we probably have about 75% to 80% of our revenue baked in for the second half of the year. And those -- that amount that's baked in is at a rate that's right around 5%. And so then the last major component relates to the transacted rates that we expect to see for the second half of the year. And so in order to hit the midpoint of our guidance, we'd have to see transacted rates probably in the mid- to upper 4 ranges. And so based upon a 5% transacted rate growth year-to-date, that seems to be quite achievable.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And do you expect the other income to grow at a slower pace than rents overall?
componenttext: And do you expect the other income to grow at a slower pace than rents overall?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we looked at our expectations for other income at the start of the year, we thought that other income would grow in about the 3% range versus 4% where we were in 2015. What we've seen through the first half of the year is other income has grown much mo
componenttext: As we looked at our expectations for other income at the start of the year, we thought that other income would grow in about the 3% range versus 4% where we were in 2015. What we've seen through the first half of the year is other income has grown much more slowly, I think we're up less than 100 basis points. That is largely attributable to lower utility expenses. And so while we don't know what's going to happen for the remainder of the year, we are able to be reimbursed for about 65% of our utility costs. So whether utilities are up or down, the impact on NOI is rather nominal.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then for the second quarter, you had weighted average rent increases of 5.3%. And did I hear you say that, that was 100 basis points better than last year?
componenttext: And then for the second quarter, you had weighted average rent increases of 5.3%. And did I hear you say that, that was 100 basis points better than last year?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: So I'm wondering what maybe is driving that comp, because when I look at the same-store pool for weighted average rent increases from the 2Q supplemental from last year, it was 5.4%. So I would have thought it was a 10 basis point decrease. I'm wondering what's the, I guess, 110 basis points variance between those 2 numbers?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's a lot of very similar terms. So when we talk about the rent increase, that is the rate of increase on our in-place leases during the quarter that is pre-adjustment for both the impact of other income and occupancy. So once you take into accou
componenttext: Yes. There's a lot of very similar terms. So when we talk about the rent increase, that is the rate of increase on our in-place leases during the quarter that is pre-adjustment for both the impact of other income and occupancy. So once you take into account those 2 factors, you get the 5.4 number that you referenced, which, on an equivalent basis, would be the 4 2 that we saw. But if you look at just the rents, the rents are somewhat accelerated to 100 bps.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So where it says weighted average rent increase in the supplemental on Page 2, that's really more of a revenue number?
componenttext: Okay. So where it says weighted average rent increase in the supplemental on Page 2, that's really more of a revenue number?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me grab my supplemental. You're on Page 2 of the release?
componenttext: Let me grab my supplemental. You're on Page 2 of the release?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly. It says 5.3% on the second quarter.
componenttext: Exactly. It says 5.3% on the second quarter.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: There are 2 numbers. I'm catching up to you now, Nick. There are 2 numbers that are both 5.3%. If you look at our transacted rates during the second quarter, on a blended basis, those are up 5.3%. That is on the middle of the page. If you also look on tha
componenttext: There are 2 numbers. I'm catching up to you now, Nick. There are 2 numbers that are both 5.3%. If you look at our transacted rates during the second quarter, on a blended basis, those are up 5.3%. That is on the middle of the page. If you also look on that same page, on the top table, we have a line that's average rent per apartment home, and the year-over-year variance there is also 5.3%. So that might be the course of -- the cause of the confusion. And if you like to talk about it further, please give me a call, and we'll work through the details.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And the next question comes from John Kim of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a 2-part question on Indigo. First of all, can you quantify how much it is leasing above underwriting? I think last quarter, you said mid-single digit. And then the second part is did the delay in acquiring Indigo contribute to your raising FFO guida
componenttext: Just a 2-part question on Indigo. First of all, can you quantify how much it is leasing above underwriting? I think last quarter, you said mid-single digit. And then the second part is did the delay in acquiring Indigo contribute to your raising FFO guidance? Because I think it was initially dilutive to earnings.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So John, in terms of the underwriting, yes, it remains in single digits above the rents we're achieving or single digits above the underwriting, and I'll let Paul comment on the timing as it relates to.
componenttext: Yes. So John, in terms of the underwriting, yes, it remains in single digits above the rents we're achieving or single digits above the underwriting, and I'll let Paul comment on the timing as it relates to.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. John, you're exactly right. The delay in the acquisition of Indigo will be a net positive for Aimco, not only from a 2016 economic endpoint, but more importantly, from an IRR standpoint. Because as we underwrote the project, we expected the building
componenttext: Yes. John, you're exactly right. The delay in the acquisition of Indigo will be a net positive for Aimco, not only from a 2016 economic endpoint, but more importantly, from an IRR standpoint. Because as we underwrote the project, we expected the building to be completely empty on day 1. And so now when we take it over, it'll be, at least partially, partially leased, and we'll have income coming in from day 1. Now unfortunately, for us, there is not a real significant benefit to us in 2016. We pick up probably a few hundred thousand dollars from this delay on a bottom line basis. So it's not necessarily impactful for 2016 results.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Terry, thanks for the headlines you gave at your prepared comments. I think one of them was your portfolio is reaching an all-time high in terms of quality. I just wanted to marry that with your discussion of having a diverse portfolio. Do you wa
componenttext: And then Terry, thanks for the headlines you gave at your prepared comments. I think one of them was your portfolio is reaching an all-time high in terms of quality. I just wanted to marry that with your discussion of having a diverse portfolio. Do you want to increase your As and Bs as a percentage of your portfolio?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, thank you. We want to maintain the balance. We were 45% -- I guess about 50% As today, and that's about as high as we would like. We might get over that just based on timing, but we have no appetite for having the highest rent unless it's balanced e
componenttext: John, thank you. We want to maintain the balance. We were 45% -- I guess about 50% As today, and that's about as high as we would like. We might get over that just based on timing, but we have no appetite for having the highest rent unless it's balanced elsewhere by some inhibition against competitive new supply.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I might jump in there, John, just real quick. This is John Bezzant. On an overall portfolio basis, our rents are about 113% of the market rent throughout our portfolio. And that's -- it's riding very comfortable just above the average kind of a B, B+ port
componenttext: I might jump in there, John, just real quick. This is John Bezzant. On an overall portfolio basis, our rents are about 113% of the market rent throughout our portfolio. And that's -- it's riding very comfortable just above the average kind of a B, B+ portfolio that we're trying to craft overall.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: And next, we have a question from Drew Babin of Robert W. Baird.

componenttextpreview: Question on merchant build opportunity. Are you seeing a lot of opportunities for the merchant builder acquisition opportunity? Is there anything changed in the transaction landscape? Are you seeing more opportunities to take out developers just in the la
componenttext: Question on merchant build opportunity. Are you seeing a lot of opportunities for the merchant builder acquisition opportunity? Is there anything changed in the transaction landscape? Are you seeing more opportunities to take out developers just in the last couple of months?

componenttextpreview: This is John. We haven't seen a lot, not a market uptick in that, certainly not in the form of distress. There are plenty of developers out there that are still looking for equity and for the opportunity to put deals together. But we have not seen any, ca
componenttext: This is John. We haven't seen a lot, not a market uptick in that, certainly not in the form of distress. There are plenty of developers out there that are still looking for equity and for the opportunity to put deals together. But we have not seen any, candidly for us, in terms of an acquisition opportunity. We haven't seen anything compelling come across in quite some time.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: To be accurate to say that redevelopment opportunities in your current portfolio are currently the more attractive option?
componenttext: To be accurate to say that redevelopment opportunities in your current portfolio are currently the more attractive option?

componenttextpreview: Absolutely.
componenttext: Absolutely.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one question on Lincoln Place specifically. I know you gave color on Mid-Wilshire. You talked in the past about Lincoln Place asset being very unique, and it obviously is on the [indiscernible] market and with the amount of [indiscernible] it ha
componenttext: Okay. And one question on Lincoln Place specifically. I know you gave color on Mid-Wilshire. You talked in the past about Lincoln Place asset being very unique, and it obviously is on the [indiscernible] market and with the amount of [indiscernible] it has size of units, et cetera. Is it continuing to compete well against the new supply in the Silicon Beach area from a differentiation standpoint? Or do you think something changed there?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Drew, this is Keith. I'll help you walk through that. Thank you for the question, and it's exactly what we're seeing. Interestingly enough, when we look at Playa Vista, there's a couple of thousand new units, Irvine Company, Lincoln Properties that are pu
componenttext: Drew, this is Keith. I'll help you walk through that. Thank you for the question, and it's exactly what we're seeing. Interestingly enough, when we look at Playa Vista, there's a couple of thousand new units, Irvine Company, Lincoln Properties that are putting units in there, and they're going more vertical. We continue to see occupancy north of 95% at Lincoln Place, and we really attribute it to the fact that it is such a unique product, where you have open space between units, setbacks for a couple of hundred feet from the sidewalk with open grass spaces and, of course, the unique architecture and styling of the buildings. And so we have weathered that a little bit differently than we have seen within the marketplace. In addition to that, we continue to see the rents continue to push higher than what we're seeing in the overall LA market.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Conor Wagner of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: The next question comes from Conor Wagner of Green Street Advisors.

componenttext: That's right, Conor.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then you guys have typically seen an acceleration in new lease and renewal growth through this summer, but it looks like it's actually coming down from June. Do you expect that to come back in August and September? Or can you help us understand what's
componenttext: And then you guys have typically seen an acceleration in new lease and renewal growth through this summer, but it looks like it's actually coming down from June. Do you expect that to come back in August and September? Or can you help us understand what's going on there?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, it is Keith. I'll take it. We definitely -- we anticipate that we'll see acceleration as we work our way through the balance of the third quarter. But when we look at July, July typically is -- when we look back historically is a month in which we
componenttext: Conor, it is Keith. I'll take it. We definitely -- we anticipate that we'll see acceleration as we work our way through the balance of the third quarter. But when we look at July, July typically is -- when we look back historically is a month in which we have the greatest amount of inventory. It's kind of our peak of peak. And so to see it as we navigate through it will build momentum coming out of it.

componenttext: Conor, I'm was just going to add that to fund the acquisition of Indigo, we currently have set up in the 1031 exchange account about $290 million of proceeds. And that will cover substantially all of our costs for the acquisition of Indigo.

componenttext: Yes. I think the original guidance is $450 million in dispositions for the year. So just understanding if you have to use those additional proceeds beyond what going to go into Indigo, if that's going to go towards development or if you guys are looking for another $100 million or so in acquisition in the back half of the year?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conor, as we set up our plan for the year, we purposely back-end weighted an element of our disposition timing. And so you'll likely have noticed that our borrowings on our credit facility have ran a little bit higher than they have historically. And our
componenttext: Conor, as we set up our plan for the year, we purposely back-end weighted an element of our disposition timing. And so you'll likely have noticed that our borrowings on our credit facility have ran a little bit higher than they have historically. And our plan today is to the extent that we're able to execute on the remaining $150 million or so of dispositions, those proceeds will be used to pay down our direct credit facility balance.

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. One last, if I may. On Indigo, have you started to lease up the penthouse yet? And on a revenue basis, how much will the penthouses or the largest 3 bedrooms be for the total property?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have started leasing there on the penthouse level. It's the 10th floor. There are 3 different towers in the building and the 10th floor of each building is -- are penthouse units that we have leased there. I don't have an exact number for you toda
componenttext: Yes. We have started leasing there on the penthouse level. It's the 10th floor. There are 3 different towers in the building and the 10th floor of each building is -- are penthouse units that we have leased there. I don't have an exact number for you today of how many of the penthouses are leased. But it has been a measurable part of the leasing activity to date commensurate with the overall activity in the building. As to revenue guidance -- as to the impact, if you will, of the penthouses on the over underwriting, it's relatively marginal. They're not a big count number in the overall scheme of things, and so we are not relying on them to do returns, if you will. They're kind of part of the commodity as well.

componenttext: Just one quick one from me, and I apologize if I missed this in your prepared remarks. But I was wondering if you guys had an update to your historic tax credits and other tax benefits guidance? I think at your initial full year guidance, you guys were expecting about $19 million or so in total at the midpoint. Any update to that? Or you guys kind of tracking around that as well?

headline: Apartment Investment and Management Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Michael, thank you for the question. This is Paul. We are tracking. I think there's a couple of different numbers. The $19 million number, I believe, is the impact of the amortization of our deferred tax credit revenue, and we're on track to hit that
componenttext: Yes. Michael, thank you for the question. This is Paul. We are tracking. I think there's a couple of different numbers. The $19 million number, I believe, is the impact of the amortization of our deferred tax credit revenue, and we're on track to hit that number. But for historic tax benefits, in particular, we provided a range of I believe $9 million to $11 million, and right now, we're tracking to be within that range. I would point out that with the North Tower acceleration of Park Towne Place, we do expect to earn historic tax credits on that project. However, that won't impact our 2016 results, that will actually be a 2017 event for us.
